poem:
Māori Art: A Living Tapestry

In 600 pages, an ocean of voices,  
they weave flax, carve wood, bind history.  
Images dance like light on water,  
where ancestors wade, knee-deep in reverence.  
Māori hands caress the past,   
and with each stroke, renew their art—  
innovative, breathing, alive—  
making the world witness, listen, remember.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Our people were so innovative’: Māori art celebrated in landmark book A new landmark book celebrating Māori art has clocked up a couple of impressive firsts: not only is it the most comprehensive account of creative work by Indigenous New Zealanders ever published, it is also the first wide-ranging art history written entirely by Māori scholars. Spanning 600 pages and including more than 500 images, Toi Te Mana: An Indigenous history of Māori art was". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
